instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: (SOLVED)<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Pulsing?
threads.message: Hello, I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. I looked the board over and found corrosion near <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. I had no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> but I removed corroded capacitor and got 3.3V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. The problem is I plug in the charger to every single port and it takes 5v, 30-50 milliamps, and turns off. And the cycle repeats. For the 3 seconds its on, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.3V. Right before it turns off, PPDCIN turns to 19.89V before turning off again. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> as it had a bit of corrosion on it. Pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> goes to a test point that was corroded and is completely gone. However, this test point is not on the boardview. I have also replaced <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> from a donor, and still no luck. Any ideas?

threads.title: (SOLVED)<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Pulsing?
threads.message:
If DCIN pulses to 20V, problem shouldn't be on USB-C areas.
There should be a problem on secondary power supplies.
Check for short on all big coils.
Also try starting in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: (SOLVED)<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Pulsing?
threads.message:
I did not notice anything strange around coils. When I performed SMC Bypass, charger stays on, but does not boot. It gets stuck at 5v 50 milliamps. I looked again where the corrosion was. Turns out I am blind as a bat and the test points that were corroded are labeled on boardview. The test points are for:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: Still there but in rough shape
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>: Gone
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: Gone

Corrosion was on <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3106</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> and the testpoints.

threads.title: (SOLVED)<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Pulsing?
threads.message: I discovered my issue. Ball 53 on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> trace was broken to pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR>. had to remove underfill to see it. Ran jumper from trace to Pad 1 of <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> and it turns on no problems.
